blog.name: andrewmerediths
blog.title: you are my person
blog.description:
mary, xxvi, awkward nerd. 
gifmaker. multifandom mess (sideblog). follow from ianmharding.

summary: What about you? I’m not a Stark.
caption: What about you? I’m not a Stark.

summary:
ㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤ«i would've die to get you there»
ㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤ«if i fall, don't bring me back»
ㅤ“He remembered a time when he had thought that...
body:
ㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤ«i would’ve die to get you there»

ㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤㅤ«if i fall, don’t bring me back»

ㅤ“He remembered a time when he had thought that Lord Eddard Stark might marry him to Sansa and claim him for a son, but that had only been a child’s fancy…”

ㅤ“He thought of Sansa, brushing out Lady’s coat and singing to herself… You know nothing, Jon Snow.”

— You’re a Greyjoy. And you’re Stark.

— You’re a Targaryen. And you’re Stark.

They both always prayed for become a Stark, a member of the pack, of their real home. They’re both separated for two sides inside them: blood and «where do i belong» half. Jon chose the Night Watch over the North, and Theon betrayed the Starks.

They both did mistakes and have innumerous regrets. There’s a lot of grief, suffer and pain. There’s always remained a radiant, weak dream of being a Stark. Being Ned Stark’s true son. They’re almost equal and unequal by their actions as well.

But here’s one more thing.

They both saved Ned Stark’s daughter, they both became Sansa’s living knights. They almost died to protect her and she was the only person who brought them back to themselves. «Your name is Theon Greyjoy, do you hear me?» «Winterfell is our home. It’s ours. You’re a Stark to me». Isn’t it?

And they both aren’t her brothers. They grew up together and then were divided. They all have changed. Have been broken. Have even «died».

So why, why if there’s a Theon who can be fallen for her - there can’t be Jon Snow at all?

Jon’s heart belongs to the North, to his family. To Sansa. There’s no any man who could tear her away from his heart. He did everything for her.

Theon did everything for her. And came back for Winterfell by the belief that she’ll have him. Where’s Sansa there’s his heart as well.

Please, don’t deny they do love her.

They both would’ve die to get her safe. No matter what kind of love is this might be, but it does exist.

Sansa represents for Jon and Theon something that could never become true. Ever. But here she’s. And here they’re, starring at her breathlessly. Starring at her the way Robb Stark never would.

blog.name: catchyourdreamsbefore
blog.title: catchyourdreamsbeforetheyslipaway
blog.description:
just a small town girl who escapes the suffocating suburbs as much as she possibly can. i like pretty things, interesting art, writing, and photography. i'm a tv whore, obsessed with hollywood, and in love with hugh jackman (among other various actors).


Ask Me!

summary:
i haven’t written fanfic in years but there’s just this muse circling in my head non stop today. 
imagine Gendry asking Jon for...
body:
i haven’t written fanfic in years but there’s just this muse circling in my head non stop today.


imagine Gendry asking Jon for Arya’s hand in marriage. and jon just laughs and laughs and Gendry is like ‘oh shit, it’s because he doesn’t think i’m royal enough.’

and jon stops laughing and looks at him and goes ‘gods bless you, mate. you’d have an easier time marrying a dragon.’

reblog.comment:

blog.name: lupinusalbus
blog.title: Lupinus Albus
blog.description:
Speculations about Game of Thrones...
(mostly the show)

summary: Jon’s  Backstory via Rhaegar’s Actions and what it Means for the End of Game of Thrones
title: Jon’s  Backstory via Rhaegar’s Actions and what it Means for the End of Game of Thrones
body:
Now that Game of Thrones is reaching the end (at least as a TV show) we are seeing more of it’s loose ends starting to be resolved.  One of the biggest mysteries of the books and the show was about Jon’s origins.  A long time theory was confirmed when Jon’s true parents were revealed to be Lyanna Stark and Rhaegar Targaryen.  The fact of Jon’s true bloodline has consequences for the surface plot which is about the political maneuvering in Westeros, something about which Jon has often stayed neutral,  or even dismissed as small potatoes.  In a nutshell, Jon’s bloodline as a legitimate Targaryen entitles him to be a claimant to the Iron Throne.  That’s why the “reveal” will eventually send shockwaves through Westeros when it becomes more known.


That’s the surface story, but there is another one too, which is integral to the mystical side of show and books.  We know from Bran’s visions that the Starks, the Targaryens, and the Night King seem to be engaged in a kind of subterranean power struggle  The visions have shown images of the tragedies befalling the Starks being intercut with scenes of Dany’s Dragons and also the Night King creating new Whitewalkers and raising the dead at Hardhome.  This all suggests a magical power dynamic operating under the political surface that is influencing if not orchestrating the events.  We also know that Bran Stark is somehow the registry or “memory” for these events that the Night King would apparently like to erase.

In any event, Rhaegar Targaryen, Jon’s biological father, was a person who was heavily involved in the mystical elements of this story.  Rhaegar was born on the same evening that the summer palace of the Targaryens was destroyed in a fire.  According to the story, Aegon V was attempting to hatch dragon eggs at Summerhall and that was the cause of the disaster.  Aegon V was concerned about the waning power of the Targaryens (reminiscent of the speech Dany made to Jon at the Dragonpit), and thus his interest in bringing back the Dragons.  It is not known exactly what went terribly wrong in Aegon V’s ritual, but the procedure itself must have been similar to what Daenerys did when she hatched her eggs at the end of season one.  Rhaegar was twenty-four when he died at the Trident, so all of this happened fairly recently as it relates to Game of Thrones.

What are some of the things we know about Rhaegar?  One notable thing is his interest in prophecy and his probable association with the Ghost of High Heart, or the Wood’s Witch.  Without going into too much detail, the Ghost of High Heart was a “stooped, very short woman who has visions of the future and the past” who was involved with the Targaryens.  She was a friend of Jenny of Oldstones (of Jenny’s Song), and issued a prophecy about the Prince Who was Promised.  This lead to Aerys and Rhaella (Dany and Rhaegar’s parents) being forced to marry because the Witch predicted the “Prince” would be born of their lineage.  The Witch was also present at Summerhall during the ritual gone wrong.

Rhaegar was haunted by the tragedy and used to frequent the ruins of Summerhall, where it is theorized that he came into contact with the Ghost of High Heart from whom he received more prophecies.  These are thought to be related to his action of eloping with Lyanna Stark.  Some readers have also theorized that Jenny’s Song, recently performed on the show by Podrick Payne, was written by Rhaegar Targaryen in return for receiving prophecies from the Ghost of Highheart/Wood’s Witch.  Rhaegar’s songs, in particular “Jenny’s Song,”  were known for making female listeners cry.  At the Harrenhal tournament, where Rhaegar met Lyanna Stark, he reportedly made her cry when he played one of his songs, perhaps this one.

Everyone who follows Game of Thrones knows that Rhaegar annulled his marriage (which produced two children) from Elia Martel sometime after he eloped with (not kidnapped) Lyanna Stark after the Harrenhal Tournament.  The incident lead to Robert’s Rebellion and the deaths of thousands including Rhaeger, Elia and her children, and the Mad King.  It lead to the Targaryens losing the Iron Throne.  So what compelled Rhaegar to do it? It’s surmised that Rhaegar originally thought himself to be the “Prince” of the prophecy, but he later thought that it would be his child, who must also be of Stark lineage.  Hence, his “kidnapping” of Lyanna.

At the house of the undying, Dany has a vision of Rhaegar and Elia with the newborn Aegon (presumably the firstborn Aegon) in which Rhaegar seems to be telling Dany that “there must be one more” because “the dragon has three heads”.  The “one more” of course refers to Jon Snow, but what is his significance to Dany with reference to the prophecy?

Please see part II for more of this Theory.

Rhaegar was haunted by the tragedy and used to frequent the ruins of Summerhall, where it is theorized that he came into contact with the Ghost of High Heart from whom he received more prophecies.  These are thought to be related to his action of eloping with Lyanna Stark.  Some readers have also theorized that Jenny’s Song, recently performed on the show by Podrick Payne, was written by Rhaegar Targaryen in return for receiving prophecies from the Ghost of Highheart/Wood’s Witch.  Rhaegar’s songs, in particular “Jenny’s Song,”  were known for making female listeners cry.  At the Harrenhal tournament, where Rhaegar met Lyanna Stark, he reportedly made her cry when he played one of his songs, perhaps this one.

Everyone who follows Game of Thrones knows that Rhaegar annulled his marriage (which produced two children) from Elia Martel sometime after he eloped with (not kidnapped) Lyanna Stark after the Harrenhal Tournament.  The incident lead to Robert’s Rebellion and the deaths of thousands including Rhaeger, Elia and her children, and the Mad King.  It lead to the Targaryens losing the Iron Throne.  So what compelled Rhaegar to do it? It’s surmised that Rhaegar originally thought himself to be the “Prince” of the prophecy, but he later thought that it would be his child, who must also be of Stark lineage.  Hence, his “kidnapping” of Lyanna.

At the house of the undying, Dany has a vision of Rhaegar and Elia with the newborn Aegon (presumably the firstborn Aegon) in which Rhaegar seems to be telling Dany that “there must be one more” because “the dragon has three heads”.  The “one more” of course refers to Jon Snow, but what is his significance to Dany with reference to the prophecy?

Please see part II for more of this Theory.

You got: Jon Snow / Bran Stark

summary:
There are three patron saints of Jonsa:
1. Bryan Cogman
2. Liz Gallo (Quora Jonsa Defender)
3. Rachel Handler
Under these patron...
body:
There are three patron saints of Jonsa:

1. Bryan Cogman

2. Liz Gallo (Quora Jonsa Defender)

3. Rachel Handler


Under these patron saints, I would like to include our Sisters of House Jonsa:

@thelawyerthatwaspromised

@tiny-little-bird

@ladyandtheghost

@jonsansasource


There are so many more Jonsa defenders but to all I want to give you thanks for your metas, your GIFs, your fanfiction that gives me insomnia and hope everlasting for an ending to GoT that serves Jon Snow and Sansa Stark well. We are forever blessed by your commitment, courage and love for these two.


Thank. You. ❤️🐺🐺❤️

summary:
Also just wanted to point out again just for the people in the back 
Kind of further proves the point on why he was holding onto...
body:
Written interview from Bryan Cogman - the writer for GOT S8E2

Also just wanted to point out again just for the people in the back

Kind of further proves the point on why he was holding onto her/ holding hands hands throughout the conversation and etc. He loves her and that’s why when she brings up the throne he couldn’t give two shits about that. Because for the person he loves he would give it to her anyway.

blog.name: ruta-yawara
blog.title: There are worlds where the sky is burning

summary:
We never stood a chance
(I don't think D**** will refuse to fight, but. I think Jon told her because he felt guilty and above...
body:
We never stood a chance

(I don’t think D**** will refuse to fight, but. I think Jon told her because he felt guilty and above all because he wanted to give her a choice. To remain and fight for her own reasons and not only his. He found out she’s family too and he wants to act accordly. Another missing moment before the battle.)

*

Outside the crypts, in stark contrast to the silence that he has just left behind, the night is a swarm of men in turmoil, a constellation of braziers and campfires that flare up like fallen stars, shouts and orders given over the noise of wind.

As soon as she can, Daenerys slips away, distancing herself from him as much as possible, shortly becoming a shadow among other shadows.

For a moment he is tempted to follow her, then the horns ring again. In his suddenly white and emptied mind, he has no doubt what to do, where to go. He runs towards the battlements and his hopes are not disappointed.

They are both there and at the sound of footsteps, they turn simultaneously to look at him. They appear surprised, like they hadn’t expected to see him.

Sansa is the first to notice that something is wrong. She frowns, her eyes dancing on his face with something akin to a vigilant and cautious concern. “Where’s Daenerys?”

Arya doesn’t make a sound, but in his head he can hear a sharp voice similar to hers distinctly shouting that - we need her dragons!

He could lie, reassure them. He tilts his head a little and forces himself not to take his eyes off, bearing the silent reproach in theirs as he says, “She will not come.”

“What do you mean-” Sansa pales. “No. Tell me you didn’t. Of all the idiotic things you could have done!”

“What are you talking about?” Arya inquires.

“He told her.” Sansa’s voice is flat and weary at the same time.

He looks at them and it’s like something finally clicked in his head. Jon confusedly thinks that he should be more surprised, feel something different from this strange and absolute clear-headedness. For a moment, however, everything becomes obvious, transparent. There’s a clarity to his thinking that’s… frightening.

The truth looks at him from two pairs of eyes, unlike as sun and moon. And he loves them both, but in a different way and oh, so that’s the way things are.

“Why now? Why didn’t you wait after the battle?” Sansa doesn’t accuse him and there is a part of him that is grateful to her while another would prefer her to shout at him.

Because there may not be an after. Because it could be the last chance to say it. Because he foolishly decided to do the good, honorable and right thing. Because he is just like Father. Only he isn’t Ned Stark son, not really. Because when he discovered that Daenerys was also his family, he couldn’t keep lying to her.

“It had to be done.”

There is no need to say anything else.

“You’re an idiot,” she says and for the first time he hears what she’s not saying, but that has always been there between them, in the space that separates them, in the tension that unites them. I love you.

He smiles without smiling. “I know.”

“So what do we do now?” Arya intervenes. She doesn’t make judgments or comment on what she has just witnessed.

“We fight,” he answers without hesitation.

Arya nods, wolfish and serious. She seems hardened in iron and in the blood of a thousand battles. When she disappears, Jon wonders what truly happened to his little sister. He knows the answer. She’s dead. The girl was killed to let the woman be born, the warrior.

“You have to talk to her,” Sansa says earnestly.

“I already did. She doesn’t want to listen to me.”

Out of the corner of his eye, he sees her stiffen. “Then try again and make sure she listen to you this time.”

“You don’t understand.” He wouldn’t want to, but it’s stronger than him. Anger begins to crackle under his skin. “She thinks I want that damned throne.”

“Then convince her that’s not the case!”

“Do you think I didn’t try? You weren’t there. You didn’t see how she looked at me. Like I -” I had betrayed her.

“You’re right, I don’t know, but I can imagine it. I don’t know what it feels like to find out you have a family when you thought you were alone, but I know what it’s like when you lose it and when you get it back. In other circumstances, I would advise you to give her time. Time that we don’t have.” Sansa puts both hands against the merlons and looks down. “Without her, we don’t stand a chance,” she whispers fiercily.

The horns silence whatever he is about to say. “What did you feel?”

Sansa turns around. She’s relaxed, alert, ready for duty. Her profile is cut against the depth of the black sky. There are no stars, too much smoke to see them. It’s a pity. “When you found out. What did you feel?”

Sansa doesn’t flinch, doesn’t breathe. Then mildly, quietly, like she’s confiding a secret, she licks her lips and answers, “Relief.”

Truly, they never stood a chance.

“Do you think I didn’t try? You weren’t there. You didn’t see how she looked at me. Like I -” I had betrayed her.

“You’re right, I don’t know, but I can imagine it. I don’t know what it feels like to find out you have a family when you thought you were alone, but I know what it’s like when you lose it and when you get it back. In other circumstances, I would advise you to give her time. Time that we don’t have.” Sansa puts both hands against the merlons and looks down. “Without her, we don’t stand a chance,” she whispers fiercily.

The horns silence whatever he is about to say. “What did you feel?”

Sansa turns around. She’s relaxed, alert, ready for duty. Her profile is cut against the depth of the black sky. There are no stars, too much smoke to see them. It’s a pity. “When you found out. What did you feel?”

Sansa doesn’t flinch, doesn’t breathe. Then mildly, quietly, like she’s confiding a secret, she licks her lips and answers, “Relief.”

Truly, they never stood a chance.
